column4: hey can someone remind me how i would go about adding "root" the audio group?
when i do the command: "cat /etc/group |egrep -i audio" i get the following -> "audio:x:29:pulse" how can i add root to this group?
i think that may be a reason why i am not getting any audio from vlc...?
root doesn't need to be in any groups, it has absolute system access
why are you messing with root anyway?
that command will break your OS
you want:  useradd -a -G audio root     to add the user to the supplementary group
root doesn't gain anything by being in groups, as it can access anything at any time
why are you messing with root anyway?
when i did useradd -a -G audio root it complained about "-a" saying it was not an option...
do other apps work with sound?
everything else works with sound except vlc, such as dragon player, kmplayer, my web browswer when i play youtube videos
why are you running the GUI as root?
i understand the risks
i doubt it, heavilly
i really do
the OS isn't designed to be ran as root, which is why you  are getting issues
check the sound setting in VLC....
do you wonder why.......
since i have pulseaudio running in the background i will try the "pulseaudio" option for vlc but i doubt it will work...
try:  rm -r ~/.config/vlc      then rerun the app, or just use another player.....
is it ok as your normal user, how you are supposed to use the OS?
could use su to run VLC as your user.
